So legal documents are great for humans.
Lawyers agree, everyone else disagrees.
But they're not great for machines, because because machines require specifics.
Machines require specific URLs, machine requires specific ontologies in order to understand data.

So I look towards existing data which is provided by the European Publications Office, which actually surprisingly is the most forward working publications office in the world in terms of how it produces its documents.
So the European Publications Office basically provides a lot of metadata about all of the legislations that it provides an this metadata essentially talks about the title of the document.
When was it passed, who was it passed by?
What is it date?

Where is it being applied to?
So I found a nice little research problem right here.
Basically, how do you refer to all of these specific articles and concepts and stuff within GD PR?
So with that in mind, I looked toward creating this resource with two aims.
The first is to expose all of the specifics in GDP are like every specific point.
Every specific sub point as as a link data resource so that I could directly relate to it.

I could directly point to it, and the second was I have to define an ontology that will allow me to refer to any of the concept within the GDP are with the link back to wherever it is specifically defined in GDP are.
So the approach that I took towards this was basically the first understand document structure, which again involved legal experts.

Then I have to represent these as linked data, so I have to somehow take this structured document which is incidentally published also as XML and convert it into format which is consistent with link data principles.
Once I've done that, then I went on to identify the important terms and concepts, and finally I defined an ontology using all of those terms and concepts.
So to take you through this process, the structure of the GDP are basically consists of three top level entities.
There are recitals which are basically informative and there's 170 three of them.
There's about 10 chapters are numbered from one to X Roman numerals.
A chapter may or may not contain a section which is numbered using Arabic numerals.
Chapter will contain articles which are numbered throughout the document from 1 to 99.
So articles do not have their numbers.
Starting in each chapter or section, then there are points within an article which are again numbered for article and there are some points within points which are again numbered within points.

Definite structure here.
Chapter will contain section.
Section will contain article, although the number follows an very nice and easily representable format.
Does not happen.
So apart from that, the document is very structured, so there's 21 other citations.
So together this is kind of the text of the GDP R and at like the European Publications Office does not care how these sections are numbered, because legally these are all valid references.

But when you're dealing with linked data, we kind of want consistency in numbering, so I tried to kind of interpret chapter one as literally being chapter one rather than saying chapter I or chapter X.
But I also wanted to ensure that whenever someone referred back to Chapter X.
They actually went back and said, yeah, this is the same as chapter 10, so this was another challenge that I found when dealing with legal documents.

So based on this I looked towards identifying existing ontologies that would allow me to define legal structures, and thankfully enough, the European Publications Office again has done a marvelous job in presenting the Ely ontology, which is the European legislator Legislation, Ontology Identifier ontology.

What it basically allows you to do is it allows you to define legal entities so the European Publications Office uses this to define document metadata at the document level, but I extended the ontology to also define the document, all of the.
Structures within a document and this is done by extending the Eli Legal Resource Subdivision upper class so that it is still compatible with the rest of the year by ontology.
So you can still use or refer to GDP are with using the rest of the ontology.

So this was an important part, because I feel like a semantic web community, we have to ensure that whenever we develop something else, it has to be compatible with any work that someone else is doing.
So in my case, one of the important factors in developing this was to make sure that it is still compatible with the existing Eli ontology.
